Norland was not
en_results_raw: every day that was spent there was a day lost to her hopes of their future establishment. Her removal, therefore, was only delayed till the day after the company left the house; and was performed with as much celerity as Mrs. Dashwood, who always wished to be rated by her own good sense, could exert in the demolition of every melancholy reflection, and the arrangement of her effects. Norland was not much more than a mile from the village; and the ladies, in their way thither, were obliged to drive through it, in order to reach their own house, which was situated at its farther end. As they drove, Marianne, who had been very little in the village, was looking with great curiosity at the cottages, and wondering to which of them she would be most likely to find a tenant, when Margaret, who had been leaning forward to look over the carriage, suddenly exclaimed, "Look, look, mamma, there is the cottage we are going to live in!" and pointed to a small house, which was separated from the road by a little garden, and stood at the end of a short lane, which was bounded on one side by a wood, and on the other by a field. Mrs. Dashwood, who had been equally anxious to see the house, was delighted with its situation, and still more with the appearance of the house itself, which was small, but neat and comfortable-looking. She was also pleased to see that it was surrounded by a garden, which, though small, was well laid out, and stocked with a variety of flowers and shrubs. As they drew nearer to the house, Marianne, who had been silent for some time, suddenly spoke, "Mamma, I do not like the situation of this house; it is too near the village, and I fear we shall be disturbed by the noise of the villagers." Mrs. Dashwood, who had been thinking the same thing, was glad to find that her daughter shared her opinion, and she replied, "I was thinking the same thing, my dear; but we must make the best of it, and I daresay we shall soon get used to it." As they approached the house, they saw a woman standing at the door, who, as they drove up, came forward to meet them. She was a stout, good-looking woman, with a pleasant face, and a civil manner. "Welcome, ladies, to Barton Cottage," said she; "I am Mrs. Jennings, the housekeeper; I hope you will find everything comfortable." Mrs. Dashwood, who was pleased with the woman's appearance, and her manner, replied, "Thank you, Mrs. Jennings; we are glad to be here, and we hope to be comfortable." As they alighted from the carriage, Mrs. Jennings showed them into the house, and they were soon settled in their new home.

The tears that had been welling up in her eyes finally broke free, and she wept, the music still clutched tightly in her grasp.

en_first_half: "I have frequently detected myself in such kind of mistakes," said Elinor, "in a total misapprehension of character in some point or other: fancying people so much more gay or grave, or ingenious or stupid than they really are,
en_second_half: and I can hardly tell why or in what the deception originated. Sometimes one is guided by what they say of themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them, without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge."
en_results: and I have usually found that I have been most mistaken where I have been most positive. It is a common error, I believe, to suppose that the men whom one knows are the only men in the world, and that the women whom one sees are
en_results_raw: and I have usually found that I have been most mistaken where I have been most positive. It is a common error, I believe, to suppose that the men whom one knows are the only men in the world, and that the women whom one sees are the only women. But there are so many men, and so many women, that it is impossible to know them all, or even to know much of any of them. And yet, we are always making judgments, and forming opinions, and deciding characters, as if we had a perfect knowledge of the whole human race. It is a strange thing, but it is a fact, that we are more apt to be deceived by our own preconceptions, than by any actual misinformation that we may receive from others. We see things, not as they are, but as we expect them to be; and we judge people, not by what they are, but by what we think they ought to be. And so, we are constantly making mistakes, and constantly discovering that our mistakes are greater than we had supposed.

en_second_half: was. I detest jargon of every kind, and sometimes I have kept my feelings to myself, because I could find no language to describe them in but what was worn and hackneyed out of all sense and meaning."
en_results: is. But I am convinced that to a true admirer of nature, it is not merely a vague pleasure that is derived from the possession of a favourite haunt, but a source of elevated feelings, and of exquisite
en_results_raw: is. But I am convinced that to a true admirer of nature, it is not merely a vague pleasure that is derived from the possession of a favourite haunt, but a source of elevated feelings, and of exquisite delight. The picturesque beauty of a scene, the grandeur of a mountain, or the tranquillity of a lake, are not merely pleasing to the eye, but they have a power to awaken the imagination, and to stir the soul. And it is this, I think, that constitutes the true charm of landscape scenery, and that makes it a source of such deep and lasting pleasure to those who have the good fortune to be able to appreciate it. But, alas, this pleasure is not confined to the few who have the leisure and the means to indulge in it; it is a pleasure that is open to all, and that may be enjoyed by the humblest and the most lowly, as well as by the wealthy and the great.

en_results: no difficulty at all. She could have repressed every thought of the nature which had tormented her, on first learning the discovery of Edward's engagement, entirely, had her temper been as phlegmatic as that of her sister. But Marianne's was all sensibility;
en_results_raw: no difficulty at all. She could have repressed every thought of the nature which had tormented her, on first learning the discovery of Edward's engagement, entirely, had her temper been as phlegmatic as that of her sister. But Marianne's was all sensibility; and the idea of Edward's being so near, yet not near enough to see her, was extremely painful. She could not help thinking of him, and of his sisters; and of their kindness to her; and of their probable surprise at her not being with them; and of their possible disappointment at not seeing her; and of the awkwardness of meeting them after such a separation; and of the necessity of explaining her absence; and of the difficulty of doing so, without betraying her own feelings; and of the impossibility of concealing them entirely. The more she thought of the writer's words, the more she felt her resentment growing, until it seemed as if it would burst forth in some irreparable act, and she was obliged to exert all her self-control to prevent herself from giving way to the passion that was raging within her. en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

I must not be understood to mean that I am convinced of this; but it is natural to suppose, that a man of Mr. Willoughby's character, and with his connections, would not throw himself away on a portionless girl, without some motive that could be answered in due time. I do not mean to press this; but it is a consideration which you will naturally take into your account, when you are thinking of your sister's future. I must now leave you to your own reflections; but I shall be glad to hear from you again soon, and to know how you all are. I shall be at home for some time, and hope to see you here. I must say, I am very much concerned for your sister; and I do not think she can be too cautious in her intercourse with Mr. Willoughby. I am, dear sister, your affectionate brother.

Lúc ấy cử chỉ của tôi hẳn là kỳ lạ đối với cô, nhưng bây giờ cô đã hiểu tại sao. Làm cho hai cô đau khổ thấy bị lừa dối như thế; thấy em gái cô... nhưng tôi làm gì được? Elinor smiled, and shook her head, and said, "I am not afraid of not being liked; I am only afraid of being liked too well." "What do you mean?" asked Marianne. "I mean," replied Elinor, "that I am afraid of being liked too well by the wrong people. I am afraid of being liked too well by those who do not know me, and who may like me for the wrong reasons. I am afraid of being liked too well by those who may not like me for myself, but for something else." Marianne looked at her sister with surprise, and said, "I do not understand you. What do you mean by the wrong people?" "I mean," replied Elinor, "those who may like me for my family, or for my connections, or for my fortune, rather than for myself. I am afraid of being liked too well by those who may not like me for my character, or for my accomplishments, but for something else. I am afraid of being liked too well by those who may not like me for what I am, but for what I have." Marianne looked at her sister with a mixture of surprise and admiration, and said, "You are very wise, Elinor. You are very wise to think of these things, and to be afraid of being liked too well by the wrong people." Elinor smiled, and said, "I am not wise, Marianne. I am only cautious. I am only afraid of being hurt, and of being disappointed. I am only afraid of being liked too well by those who may not like me for myself." Marianne nodded, and said, "I understand you, Elinor. I understand you perfectly. You are afraid of being liked too well by those who may not like you for yourself, but for something else. You are afraid of being hurt, and of being disappointed. You are afraid of being liked too well by the wrong people." Elinor smiled, and said, "Yes, Marianne. That is exactly what I am afraid of. I am afraid of being liked too well by the wrong people, and of being hurt, and of being disappointed." Marianne nodded, and said, "I will always be careful, Elinor. I will always be careful to like you for yourself, and not for anything else. I will always be careful to like you for your character, and for your accomplishments, and not for your family, or your connections, or your fortune." Elinor smiled, and said, "Thank you, Marianne. Thank you for understanding me, and for being careful. I am very grateful to you, Marianne." Marianne smiled, and said, "I will always be careful, Elinor. I will always be careful to like you for yourself, and not for anything else." And the two sisters sat together in silence for a few moments, enjoying each other's company, and feeling happy and content.
